docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on honoring a dying parent’s donations that go against your beliefs, voting in a country you don’t live in and more.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on honoring a dying parent’s donations that go against your beliefs, voting in a country you don’t live in and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last summer, I had to tell my father that he had terminal lung cancer. We had an opportunity to make him as comfortable as possible for however much time he might have left, and I encouraged him to focus on that. He begrudgingly agreed.

headline.main: Must I Honor My Dad’s Gifts to Political Groups?
headline.print_headline: Must I Honor My Dad’s Gifts to Political Groups?

docs.abstract: Acquaint yourself with bivalve anatomy. Protect your hand.
docs.snippet: Acquaint yourself with bivalve anatomy. Protect your hand.
docs.lead_paragraph: “You’re going to butcher it the first time; it’s O.K.,” says Rigo Alvarado, 27, who shucks hundreds of oysters a night behind the raw bar at Connie and Ted’s, a seafood restaurant in West Hollywood. A shucker should be careful not to puncture the organism inside. Don’t spill any juices or leave behind bits of shell shrapnel. An opened oyster should look unmolested. “Like it doesn’t know it’s missing its shell,” Alvarado says.

docs.lead_paragraph: The spring/summer 2018 collections, held in Paris this week, were a feast for the eyes.

headline.main: Our Favorite Images from the Couture Shows

docs.abstract: Extreme fatigue and muscle pain led to one diagnosis. Enlarged lymph nodes led to another.
docs.snippet: Extreme fatigue and muscle pain led to one diagnosis. Enlarged lymph nodes led to another.
docs.lead_paragraph: It was Christmas Day when the 34-year-old woman acknowledged that something was really wrong. Her husband — like her, a physician at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. — drew the short straw and had to work that day. Home alone with her children — the baby nearly 1, the other nearly 3 — she realized she was literally too tired to put the kids to bed. When her husband got home, well after their bedtime, he scooped up the baby and the child and took them upstairs. As they disappeared into the bedroom, she struggled to follow. She held onto the banister with both hands. Lifting her legs was real work. She felt as if weights were attached to her feet. How did she get to be this tired?

headline.main: Had Two Diseases Struck at Once?
headline.print_headline: Had Two Diseases Struck at Once?

docs.abstract: Normally a workhorse, he began feeling strangely exhausted. Then he ended up in the intensive-care unit.
docs.snippet: Normally a workhorse, he began feeling strangely exhausted. Then he ended up in the intensive-care unit.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Something’s wrong,” the woman told the young doctor, her face lined with worry. “This is not my husband.” The 68-year-old man lay unmoving in the hospital bed, his eyes dull, his face expressionless. His wife stood by him, as she had for nearly four decades of marriage. You don’t know him, she said, but if you did, you’d know that something is not right.

headline.main: Tests Indicated His Infection Was Getting Better. Why Did He Feel Worse?
headline.print_headline: After the man was treated for a bad infection, tests indicated he was getting better. So why was he feeling weaker by the day?

docs.abstract: Her heart stopped, and blood began pouring out of her nose and mouth. What was going on?
docs.snippet: Her heart stopped, and blood began pouring out of her nose and mouth. What was going on?
docs.lead_paragraph: “Don’t worry,” the teenage girl said as she lowered herself to the ground. It was her last day at her suburban New Jersey high school, and she and her friends were in the lounge, studying for their very last exam.

headline.main: Why Was This Teenager Bleeding So Excessively?
headline.print_headline: A teenager’s heart stops, and blood starts pouring out of her nose and mouth. What is going on?

docs.abstract: Prime your eyes — have a search image in mind. Consult a tide chart.
docs.snippet: Prime your eyes — have a search image in mind. Consult a tide chart.
docs.lead_paragraph: “It helps to have a search image in your mind,” says José H. Leal, the science director and curator at the Bailey-Matthews National Shell Museum in Florida. Research ahead of time what kind of mollusks you might encounter so that your eyes are primed to pick out specific shapes and colors. Leal has collected seashells since he was a boy in Rio de Janeiro. On his first trip to New York, in his 20s, he was so shell-focused that he dove to the sidewalk before realizing that what he thought were small, unusual clams were actually pistachio shells. “You get fixated,” he says.

docs.abstract: Tuck chin to chest. If you’re going down head first, use your arms as a “crumple zone.”
docs.snippet: Tuck chin to chest. If you’re going down head first, use your arms as a “crumple zone.”
docs.lead_paragraph: “Don’t jam yourself into the ground like a lawn dart,” says Austin Anderson, a trick rider and horse stuntman from Troup, Tex. You’ll have a few fractions of a second in the air before you land; use them to protect yourself by tucking your chin to your chest and preparing to roll, which will increase your deceleration time and distribute the force of the impact over more of your body.

headline.main: How to Fall Off a Horse
headline.print_headline: How to Fall Off A Horse
